channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Egyptians Mock Ads Promoting New Constitution With Typos and Stock Images
item.description: A campaign to win support for Egypt’s new constitution got off to a rocky start when bloggers noticed that a banner promoting the document misspelled the word for “Egyptians” in Arabic and used stock images of foreigners.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Attempted Coup in South Sudan, President Says
item.description: President Salva Kiir said soldiers loyal to the former vice president had tried to orchestrate a coup but that his government was firmly in control.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: President Salva Kiir of South Sudan said Monday in a televised address to the nation that the military had foiled a coup.

item.title: Global Health: A Simple Community Health Remedy in Mali
item.description: Deploying community health workers to treat sick children rapidly can make an enormous difference in how many live and how many die, according to a study done in Mali.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: News Analysis: In Thailand, Rallying Cry Is Against Too Much Democracy
item.description: The country is witnessing a struggle between a dominant majority and a minority frustrated that its voice is not being heard and anxious over the fate of an ailing king.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Anti-government protesters during a demonstration in Bangkok last week.

item.title: Europe’s Central Bank Loses Key Voice as Top German Plans an Exit
item.description: The departure of Jörg Asmussen for a post in the new Merkel government could open the door for a woman to join the central bank’s top ranks.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Jörg Asmussen often helped communicate E.C.B. policy to a wary German public.

item.title: Russia Deploys Missiles in Western Region
item.description: The Defense Ministry said the deployment of short-range Iskander missiles did not violate treaties, but analysts saw the move as a sign of heightened tensions.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Interpreter at Mandela Service Is Tied to Deadly 2003 Attack
item.description: News reports said that Thamsanqa Jantjie was part of a mob that burned two men to death after they had stolen a television.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON

item.title: Syria Activists Say Dozens Killed in Aleppo Air Assault
item.description: Reports by the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and others said helicopters dropped barrels filled with TNT and shrapnel on 13 neighborhoods.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMAD GHANNAM and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Israel and Lebanon Try to Defuse Tensions After Cross-Border Shooting
item.description: Military liaison officers met with representatives of the United Nations peacekeeping force after an Israeli soldier was killed and Israeli forces returned fire.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Customs Union Not on Agenda of Ukranian-Russian Talks, Officials Say
item.description: Statements by officials from both countries before Viktor F. Yanukovich and Vladimir V. Putin meet on Tuesday seemed aimed at avoiding further antagonism of protesters in Kiev.
item.category: Customs Union of Russia, Belarus and Kazakhstan
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers guarded barricades in Independence square in Kiev, on Monday.

item.title: Police and ‘Rioters’ in Fatal Clash in Western China
item.description: At least 16 people were killed near Kashgar, a part of the Xinjiang region beset with tensions between Muslim Uighurs and the government authorities.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: U.N. Seeks Record Sum for Humanitarian Aid in 2014
item.description: Half the unprecedented $13 billion sought by the United Nations for emergency relief would go to the Syria crisis.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Letter from Europe: Bullied by Russia, but Resolute
item.description: Moldova has learned diplomatic and economic lessons from its confrontation with Russia over its association with the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: The Lede: American Who Killed for Iran’s Revolution in 1980 Resurfaces in C.I.A. Spy Drama
item.description: The C.I.A. contractor who disappeared during a 2007 trip to Iran had traveled there to meet with a man whose life story could provide Hollywood screenwriters with material for a sequel to “Argo.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 16
item.description: A wholesale poultry market in Mumbai, Maharashtra.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Memo From Berlin: As Merkel Embarks on Third Term, Critics Urge Her to Be Daring
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany’s legacy could be in Europe, nurturing its fragile economic recovery and encouraging further European integration.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany at a news conference in Berlin on Sunday to discuss her new government. She reached a coalition deal over the weekend with the Social Democrats.

item.title: Dozens of Iraqis Killed in Attacks
item.description: A string of assaults in Baghdad and around the country followed 19 killings over the weekend that made December one of Iraq’s bloodiest months in five years.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: India Ink: Are Women Any Safer in India?
item.description: In the year after the Dec. 16, 2012, gang rape in Delhi, human rights lawyers and activists say key milestones were reached in the campaign against sexual violence, yet much work needs to be done.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Protesters during a demonstration to mark the first anniversary of the Dec. 16, 2012 gang rape in New Delhi on Monday.

item.title: South Sudan President Says Coup Has Been Repulsed
item.description: President Salva Kiir said to the nation that the military had foiled a coup orchestrated by “a group of soldiers allied with the former vice president.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Regulations Will Increase Commercialization of Wild Animals, Experts Say
item.description: Proposed new state regulations will increase the exploitation of wild animals for commercial use and in circuses, animal rights advocates and academics say.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A macaque is chained to a wall in Suzhou to strengthen its legs for a circus performance.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Celebrates Lunar Probe and Announces Return Plans
item.description: China’s plan to send an unmanned craft to the moon in 2017 that will land and return with samples suggests that the country will continue the rapid pace of its space program.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: This screen grab taken from state television footage shows a photo of the Jade Rabbit moon rover taken by the Chang'e-3 probe lander.

item.title: South Korean Leader Warns of Possible ‘Provocations’ From North
item.description: Citing uncertainty about the North Korean regime following a dramatic purge, President Park Geun-hye ordered the military and police to step up their vigilance.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Case Against Activist Xu Zhiyong to Focus on Public Protests
item.description: The case against Xu Zhiyong, one of China’s most prominent human rights activists, is being built around his attempts to involve the public in calling for educational parity and disclosure of wealth by officials.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: India Ink: A Year Later, Family of Delhi Gang Rape Victim Press for ‘Full Justice’
item.description: Badrinath Singh and Asha Devi say they won’t rest until the juvenile who murdered their daughter gets the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Asha Devi, mother of the Delhi gang rape victim, at her house in Dwarka on the outskirts of New Delhi on Dec. 2.

item.title: Lawmakers Fault BBC Leaders Over Severance Pay
item.description: A report by an oversight committee of the British Parliament said that “cronyism” at a “dysfunctional” BBC led to executives getting larger payoffs than they deserved.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
